data.title: ‎‘Río escondido’ review by Scott Kelly • Letterboxd
data.meta_description: So solemn and sincere it almost collapses under its own weight. Lots of government backed patriotic pro-church earnest do-gooderism with Maria Felix, when not vaccinating peasants against smallpox or teaching ragamuffins their ABCs, staring pensively out at big sky vistas while her hair floats in the breeze. The reformist intentions are admirable, I suppose, but it often plays like the most gorgeously shot PSA. One of the more Fordian looking Emilio Fernández films - this just following John Ford’s own Fernández produced Gabriel Figueroa shot The Fugitive (which seems an under appreciated Ford film to me). It’s not deep until
data.text:
So solemn and sincere it almost collapses under its own weight. Lots of government backed patriotic pro-church earnest do-gooderism with Maria Felix, when not vaccinating peasants against smallpox or teaching ragamuffins their ABCs, staring pensively out at big sky vistas while her hair floats in the breeze. The reformist intentions are admirable, I suppose, but it often plays like the most gorgeously shot PSA. One of the more Fordian looking Emilio Fernández films - this just following John Ford’s own Fernández produced Gabriel Figueroa shot The Fugitive (which seems an under appreciated Ford film to me). It’s not deep until the final reel that Felix gets to stretch any acting muscle where melodrama inevitably raises its glorious(?)/ugly(?) head. Fernández would revisit this type of material in 1962 with Pueblito (Little Town).

➡️ Emilio Fernández, Ranked
